objinfo.numberleaves: 2A double sheet written on three sides.

provenance.name: City of Westminster Archive Centre
provenance.note: The letter was sold along with the letters of 11 Sept., end of Sept., 2 Oct. 1800, 10 May, 1801, 10 Jan., 22 Nov. (both parts) 1802, 25 Spril, 6 July, 16 Aug. 1803 by Captain Frederick Butts in about 1906 to W. Graham Robertson, who allowed them to be reproduced in 1926 and bequeathed them in 1948 to Mr. Kerrison Preston, who gave them in 1967 to the Westminster Arhives.

repository.repositoryid: Preston Blake Collection: Blake-Butts Letters & Receipts (1)

objnote.p: Bentley (*Writings*, volume 2, page 1541) reads this letter dated 23 September 1800 as 22 September 1800 and remarks "since the letter was postmarked on its receipt in the London Post Office'SEP 23/ 1800' and since letters posted in Chichester arrived in London the next day, this letter must have been posted on 22 Sept. Presumably it was written on the day it was posted."
A double leaf written on three sides.
The stamp "Chichester" overlaps the name Butts.
Lines 5-8 are written in the left margin of Object 1.

desc.objtitle: Dear Friend of my Angels, Object 2

objnote.p: A double sheet written on three sides.
There is a tear on the left side of the letter and part of the red wax seal is still attached.

lg.l: Dear Friend of My Angels
We are safe arrived at our Cottage without accident or hindrance
thothough it was between Eleven & Twelve O Clock at night before we could get
home. owing to the necessary shifting of our boxes & portfolios from one
Chaise to another. We had Seven different Chaises & as many different
drivers. All upon the road was chearfulnesscheerfulness & welcome thothough our luggage
was very heavy there was no grumbling at all. We traveldtraveled throthrough a most
beautiful country on a most glorious day. Our Cottage is more beautiful
than I thought it & also more convenient. for thothough small it is well pro-proportioned
portiondproportioned & if I should ever build a Palace it would be only My CottagePart of the word "portiond" has been partially removed where the paper is torn.
Enlarged. Please to tell MrsMrs Butts that we have dedicated a Chamber

erher Service & that is has a very fine view of the Sea. MrMr Hayley The first two words of line 11 have been wholly or partially removed where the paper is torn, probably removing the words "to her". Only "r" is legible. Erdman (page 711) reads "to her" without comment or brackets.
receivdreceived me with his usual brotherly affection. My Wife & Sister areThe first word of line 13 shows wear.
both very well and courting Neptune for an Embrace. whose terrors this
morning made them afraid but whose mildness is often Equal to his terrors
The Villagers of Felpham are not meer- Rustics they are polite &
modest. Meat is cheaper than in London but the sweet air & the voices
of winds trees & birds & the odoursodors of the happy ground makes it a
dwelling for immortals. Work will go on here with God speed --
A roller & two harrows lie before my window. I met a plow on my
first going out at my gate the first morning after my arrival & the
Plowboy said to the Plowman. "Father The Gate is Open" I have begunAn ink mark appears here, slightly overlapping the comma.

objnote.p: A double sheet written on three sides.
Object three appears to be glued to the back side of Object 2.

lg.l: to Work & find that I can work with greater pleasure than ever. Hope
soon to give you a proof that Felpham is propitious to the Arts.
God bless you. I shall wait for you on tuesday Evening as usual. PrayKeynes (*Letters*, page 24) reads "tuesday" as "Tuesday".
give My & My wife & sisters love & respects to MrsMrs Butts, accept them
yourself & believe me for ever
Your affectionate & obliged Friend
William BlakeA small, isolated ink mark appears at the beginning of this line.
My Sister will be in town in a week & bring with her your account
& whatever else I can finish.Direct to MrMr
Blake: Felpham near Chichester
